unit_title: Center of Mass: Continuous Objects and Integration Methods
subject: AP Physics C: Mechanics
expanded_description: This unit extends center of mass concepts to continuous objects using integration methods. Students will learn to apply calculus to determine mass distributions, set up proper integrals for various geometries, and calculate centers of mass for one-dimensional, two-dimensional, and three-dimensional continuous objects with both uniform and variable density.
learning_objectives: Set up and evaluate integrals for center of mass of continuous objects
Apply density functions to determine mass distributions
Calculate centers of mass for 1D, 2D, and 3D objects using integration
Handle both uniform and non-uniform density distributions
Use symmetry to simplify center of mass calculations
Apply integration methods to complex geometric shapes
prerequisites: Mastery of center of mass for discrete systems (Unit 4.1)
Proficiency with single and multiple integration
Understanding of density concepts and mass distribution
Familiarity with coordinate systems and geometric relationships
Ability to work with basic volume and area elements

principles.principle: Fundamental Integration Framework for Continuous Objects
principles.statement: Continuous center of mass calculations require systematic integration: General Formulas: $x_{cm} = \frac{1}{M}\int x\, dm$, $y_{cm} = \frac{1}{M}\int y\, dm$, $z_{cm} = \frac{1}{M}\int z\, dm$; Total mass: $M = \int dm$. Mass Elements by Dimension: 1D objects: $dm = \lambda(x)\, dx$ (linear density); 2D objects: $dm = \sigma(x,y)\, dA$ (areal density); 3D objects: $dm = \rho(x,y,z)\, dV$ (volume density). Density Functions: Constant density: $\rho$ uniform; Position-dependent: $\rho(x,y,z)$; Geometric dependence: $\rho(r)$, $\rho(\theta)$, etc.; Piecewise definitions for composite objects. Coordinate Elements: Cartesian: $dV = dx\,dy\,dz$, $dA = dx\,dy$; Polar/cylindrical: $dV = r\,dr\,d\theta\,dz$, $dA = r\,dr\,d\theta$; Spherical: $dV = r^2\sin\phi\,dr\,d\phi\,d\theta$. Integration Strategy: 1. Identify object dimension and symmetry; 2. Choose optimal coordinate system; 3. Define density function and mass element; 4. Set up integrals for mass and moments; 5. Determine integration limits; 6. Evaluate integrals; 7. Interpret results. Verification Methods: Check dimensional consistency; Verify symmetry predictions; Test limiting cases; Compare with known results for standard shapes.
principles.application: Set up integrals for continuous center of mass calculations. Apply density functions to mass distributions. Choose appropriate coordinate systems and mass elements. Evaluate integrals for various geometric shapes. Verify results using multiple methods. Interpret physical significance of calculated centers of mass.
principles.example: Uniform rod center of mass. Circular plate center of mass. Solid sphere center of mass. Variable density beam analysis. Composite object center of mass. Symmetric object verification.
principles.analogy: Continuous center of mass integration is like calculating the population center of a city - instead of counting individual people (discrete particles), you integrate population density over area (continuous distribution), using census tract data (density functions) and geographic coordinates (integration variables) to find the weighted average position where the population is concentrated

worked_examples.title: Uniform Thin Rod Center of Mass
worked_examples.problem: Find the center of mass of a uniform thin rod of length L and mass M. Verify using symmetry and calculate for a rod with linear density λ(x) = kx.

step_by_step.explanation: Place rod along x-axis from x=0 to x=L; Uniform density: λ = M/L
$dm = \lambda\, dx = \frac{M}{L} dx$
$x_{cm} = \frac{1}{M} \int x\, dm = \frac{1}{M} \int_0^L x \cdot \frac{M}{L} dx = \frac{1}{L} \int_0^L x\, dx$
$x_{cm} = \frac{1}{L} \left[ \frac{x^2}{2} \right]_0^L = \frac{1}{L} \cdot \frac{L^2}{2} = \frac{L}{2}$
Uniform rod has reflection symmetry about midpoint; CM must be at center
λ(x) = kx; Total mass: $M = \int_0^L kx\, dx = k\left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^L = \frac{kL^2}{2}$
$x_{cm} = \frac{1}{M} \int_0^L x \cdot kx\, dx = \frac{1}{kL^2/2} \int_0^L kx^2\, dx = \frac{2}{L^2} \left[\frac{x^3}{3}\right]_0^L = \frac{2}{L^2} \cdot \frac{L^3}{3} = \frac{2L}{3}$
With increasing density, CM shifts toward heavier end; From L/2 to 2L/3

worked_examples.final_answer: Uniform rod: x_cm = L/2; Variable density rod: x_cm = 2L/3

image.caption: Center of mass calculation for uniform and variable density rods

worked_examples.title: Semicircular Wire Center of Mass
worked_examples.problem: Find the center of mass of a uniform semicircular wire of radius R and mass M.

step_by_step.explanation: Place semicircle in upper half-plane, center at origin; By symmetry, x_cm = 0; Need to find y_cm
Use polar coordinates: $dm = \lambda R\, d\theta$, where $\lambda = \frac{M}{\pi R}$ (mass per unit length)
For angle θ, y = R sinθ; $dm = \frac{M}{\pi R} \cdot R\, d\theta = \frac{M}{\pi} d\theta$
$y_{cm} = \frac{1}{M} \int y\, dm = \frac{1}{M} \int_0^\pi (R\sin\theta) \cdot \frac{M}{\pi} d\theta = \frac{R}{\pi} \int_0^\pi \sin\theta\, d\theta$
$y_{cm} = \frac{R}{\pi} \left[ -\cos\theta \right]_0^\pi = \frac{R}{\pi} \left[ -(-1) - (-1) \right] = \frac{R}{\pi} (1 + 1) = \frac{2R}{\pi}$
x_cm = 0 (by symmetry), y_cm = 2R/π
y_cm ≈ 0.6366R (above center)
For large N discrete points, weighted average gives similar result

classifications.note: Key principle: For 2D objects, $dm = \sigma(x,y)\, dA$, where σ is areal density (mass per unit area)

principles.statement: Two-dimensional center of mass calculations employ area integration: General Formulas: $x_{cm} = \frac{1}{M}\iint x\, dm$, $y_{cm} = \frac{1}{M}\iint y\, dm$; $M = \iint dm$. Area Elements: Cartesian: $dA = dx\,dy$; Polar: $dA = r\,dr\,d\theta$; Other coordinates as needed. Density Types: Uniform density: $\sigma = constant$; Position-dependent: $\sigma(x,y)$; Radial dependence: $\sigma(r)$; Angular dependence: $\sigma(\theta)$; Composite definitions. Symmetry Utilization: Reflection symmetry → CM on symmetry line; Rotational symmetry → CM at center; Multiple symmetries → CM at intersection; Asymmetric objects require full integration. Integration Limits: Rectangular: constant x,y limits; Circular: r from 0 to R, θ from 0 to 2π; General regions: functional limits; Piecewise definitions for complex shapes. Coordinate Choices: Cartesian: best for rectangular domains; Polar: best for circular domains; Mixed approaches for composite shapes. Special Techniques: Subtraction method for hollow objects; Additive method for composite objects; Variable transformation for difficult integrals; Numerical methods for complex shapes.
principles.application: Calculate centers of mass for two-dimensional objects. Apply double integration techniques. Utilize symmetry to simplify calculations. Handle various coordinate systems. Work with uniform and variable density distributions. Solve practical lamina problems.
principles.example: Rectangular plate center of mass. Circular disk center of mass. Triangular plate analysis. Semicircular lamina. Composite shape center of mass. Variable density plate.
principles.analogy: 2D center of mass integration is like finding the balance point of a cutout shape - you mentally divide it into small pieces (area elements), consider both the position and density (mass weighting) of each piece, and find the weighted average position where it would balance on a pinpoint, with the shape's thickness pattern representing density variation

worked_examples.title: Semicircular Lamina Center of Mass
worked_examples.problem: Find the center of mass of a uniform semicircular lamina of radius R and mass M.

step_by_step.explanation: Place semicircle in upper half-plane, center at origin; By symmetry, x_cm = 0; Need to find y_cm
$dm = \sigma\, dA = \sigma r\, dr\, d\theta$, where $\sigma = \frac{M}{\frac{1}{2}\pi R^2} = \frac{2M}{\pi R^2}$
y = r sinθ (polar coordinates)
$M = \int_0^R \int_0^\pi \sigma r\, d\theta\, dr = \sigma \int_0^R r\, dr \int_0^\pi d\theta = \sigma \cdot \frac{R^2}{2} \cdot \pi = \frac{2M}{\pi R^2} \cdot \frac{\pi R^2}{2} = M$
$y_{cm} = \frac{1}{M} \iint y\, dm = \frac{1}{M} \int_0^R \int_0^\pi (r\sin\theta) \cdot \sigma r\, d\theta\, dr$
$y_{cm} = \frac{\sigma}{M} \int_0^R r^2\, dr \int_0^\pi \sin\theta\, d\theta$
$\int_0^R r^2\, dr = \frac{R^3}{3}$; $\int_0^\pi \sin\theta\, d\theta = 2$
$y_{cm} = \frac{\sigma}{M} \cdot \frac{R^3}{3} \cdot 2 = \frac{2\sigma R^3}{3M}$
$y_{cm} = \frac{2}{3M} \cdot \frac{2M}{\pi R^2} \cdot R^3 = \frac{4R}{3\pi}$
$y_{cm} \approx 0.4244R$; Compare with semicircular wire: 0.6366R (wire has more mass farther out)

worked_examples.title: Right Triangular Plate Center of Mass
worked_examples.problem: Find the center of mass of a uniform right triangular plate with legs of length a and b along the x and y axes.

step_by_step.explanation: Place triangle with vertices at (0,0), (a,0), (0,b); Right angle at origin
Line through (a,0) and (0,b): $\frac{x}{a} + \frac{y}{b} = 1$ or $y = b(1 - \frac{x}{a})$
$dm = \sigma\, dy\, dx$, where $\sigma = \frac{2M}{ab}$ (area = ab/2)
For each x from 0 to a, y goes from 0 to b(1 - x/a)

$M = \int_0^a \int_0^{b(1-x/a)} \sigma\, dy\, dx = \sigma \int_0^a b(1-\frac{x}{a})\, dx = \sigma b \left[x - \frac{x^2}{2a}\right]_0^a = \sigma b \cdot \frac{a}{2} = \frac{2M}{ab} \cdot \frac{ab}{2} = M$
$x_{cm} = \frac{1}{M} \int_0^a \int_0^{b(1-x/a)} x \cdot \sigma\, dy\, dx = \frac{\sigma}{M} \int_0^a x \cdot b(1-\frac{x}{a})\, dx$
$\int_0^a x(1-\frac{x}{a})\, dx = \int_0^a (x - \frac{x^2}{a})\, dx = \left[\frac{x^2}{2} - \frac{x^3}{3a}\right]_0^a = \frac{a^2}{2} - \frac{a^2}{3} = \frac{a^2}{6}$
$x_{cm} = \frac{\sigma}{M} \cdot b \cdot \frac{a^2}{6} = \frac{2M}{abM} \cdot \frac{a^2b}{6} = \frac{a}{3}$
By similar calculation or symmetry: $y_{cm} = \frac{b}{3}$
CM is at intersection of medians; One-third of the way from each side

classifications.note: Key principle: For 3D objects, $dm = \rho(x,y,z)\, dV$, where ρ is volume density (mass per unit volume)

principles.statement: Three-dimensional center of mass calculations employ volume integration: General Formulas: $x_{cm} = \frac{1}{M}\iiint x\, dm$, $y_{cm} = \frac{1}{M}\iiint y\, dm$, $z_{cm} = \frac{1}{M}\iiint z\, dm$; $M = \iiint dm$. Volume Elements: Cartesian: $dV = dx\,dy\,dz$; Cylindrical: $dV = r\,dr\,d\theta\,dz$; Spherical: $dV = r^2\sin\phi\,dr\,d\phi\,d\theta$. Density Functions: Uniform: $\rho = constant$; Position-dependent: $\rho(x,y,z)$; Radial: $\rho(r)$; Layered: $\rho(z)$; Composite definitions. Symmetry in 3D: Planar symmetry → CM in symmetry plane; Axial symmetry → CM on symmetry axis; Spherical symmetry → CM at center; Multiple symmetries reduce integration dimension. Integration Strategies: Choose coordinates matching object geometry; Determine integration limits from boundaries; Handle complex boundaries with functional limits; Use substitution for difficult integrals. Special Objects: Spheres, hemispheres, cylinders, cones, boxes; Composite solids; Hollow objects; Objects with holes; Variable cross-sections. Advanced Techniques: Order of integration optimization; Coordinate transformations; Numerical methods for complex shapes; Additive/subtractive methods for composites.

principles.analogy: 3D center of mass integration is like finding the balance point of a sculpture - you mentally slice it into tiny cubes (volume elements), account for both position and material density (mass weighting) throughout the entire volume, and determine the single point where it would balance in all directions, with the sculpture's material variations representing density changes

worked_examples.title: Solid Hemisphere Center of Mass
worked_examples.problem: Find the center of mass of a uniform solid hemisphere of radius R and mass M.

step_by_step.explanation: Place hemisphere with flat face in xy-plane, center at origin; By symmetry, x_cm = 0, y_cm = 0; Need to find z_cm
For hemisphere: r from 0 to R, φ from 0 to π/2, θ from 0 to 2π
$dV = r^2\sin\phi\, dr\, d\phi\, d\theta$
$dm = \rho\, dV$, where $\rho = \frac{M}{\frac{2}{3}\pi R^3} = \frac{3M}{2\pi R^3}$
z = r cosφ

$M = \int_0^R \int_0^{\pi/2} \int_0^{2\pi} \rho r^2\sin\phi\, d\theta\, d\phi\, dr = \rho \cdot 2\pi \int_0^R r^2\, dr \int_0^{\pi/2} \sin\phi\, d\phi = \rho \cdot 2\pi \cdot \frac{R^3}{3} \cdot 1 = \frac{3M}{2\pi R^3} \cdot \frac{2\pi R^3}{3} = M$
$z_{cm} = \frac{1}{M} \iiint z\, dm = \frac{1}{M} \int_0^R \int_0^{\pi/2} \int_0^{2\pi} (r\cos\phi) \cdot \rho r^2\sin\phi\, d\theta\, d\phi\, dr$
$z_{cm} = \frac{\rho}{M} \int_0^R r^3\, dr \int_0^{\pi/2} \cos\phi\sin\phi\, d\phi \int_0^{2\pi} d\theta$
$\int_0^R r^3\, dr = \frac{R^4}{4}$; $\int_0^{\pi/2} \cos\phi\sin\phi\, d\phi = \frac{1}{2}$; $\int_0^{2\pi} d\theta = 2\pi$
$z_{cm} = \frac{\rho}{M} \cdot \frac{R^4}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \cdot 2\pi = \frac{\rho\pi R^4}{4M}$
$z_{cm} = \frac{\pi R^4}{4M} \cdot \frac{3M}{2\pi R^3} = \frac{3R}{8}$
CM is 3R/8 above the flat face, or 3R/8 from the center toward the flat side

worked_examples.title: Variable Density Solid Cylinder
worked_examples.problem: Find the center of mass of a solid cylinder of radius R, height H, with density ρ(z) = ρ₀(1 + z/H), where z is measured from the base.

step_by_step.explanation: Use cylindrical coordinates: z from 0 to H, r from 0 to R, θ from 0 to 2π
$dV = r\, dr\, d\theta\, dz$
$dm = \rho(z)\, dV = \rho_0(1 + z/H) r\, dr\, d\theta\, dz$
$M = \int_0^H \int_0^R \int_0^{2\pi} \rho_0(1 + z/H) r\, d\theta\, dr\, dz = 2\pi\rho_0 \int_0^H (1 + z/H)\, dz \int_0^R r\, dr$

$\int_0^H (1 + z/H)\, dz = \left[z + \frac{z^2}{2H}\right]_0^H = H + \frac{H}{2} = \frac{3H}{2}$; $\int_0^R r\, dr = \frac{R^2}{2}$; $M = 2\pi\rho_0 \cdot \frac{3H}{2} \cdot \frac{R^2}{2} = \frac{3\pi\rho_0 HR^2}{2}$
By symmetry, x_cm = 0, y_cm = 0; $z_{cm} = \frac{1}{M} \iiint z\, dm = \frac{1}{M} \int_0^H \int_0^R \int_0^{2\pi} z \cdot \rho_0(1 + z/H) r\, d\theta\, dr\, dz$
$z_{cm} = \frac{2\pi\rho_0}{M} \int_0^H z(1 + z/H)\, dz \int_0^R r\, dr = \frac{2\pi\rho_0}{M} \int_0^H (z + z^2/H)\, dz \cdot \frac{R^2}{2}$
$\int_0^H (z + z^2/H)\, dz = \left[\frac{z^2}{2} + \frac{z^3}{3H}\right]_0^H = \frac{H^2}{2} + \frac{H^2}{3} = \frac{5H^2}{6}$
$z_{cm} = \frac{2\pi\rho_0}{M} \cdot \frac{5H^2}{6} \cdot \frac{R^2}{2} = \frac{5\pi\rho_0 H^2 R^2}{6M}$
$z_{cm} = \frac{5\pi\rho_0 H^2 R^2}{6} \cdot \frac{2}{3\pi\rho_0 H R^2} = \frac{5H}{9}$
With increasing density upward, CM shifts upward from H/2 (uniform) to 5H/9 ≈ 0.556H

common_misconceptions: Thinking integration is always necessary for continuous objects
Believing CM always coincides with geometric center
Confusing different types of density (linear, areal, volume)
Thinking coordinate choice affects the physical CM location
Believing symmetry always guarantees CM at geometric center with variable density
Confusing integration limits for different coordinate systems
Thinking all 3D integrals are equally difficult regardless of coordinate choice
Believing variable density problems require completely different approaches
real_world_applications: Vehicle and aircraft center of mass determination
summary: Center of mass calculations for continuous objects extend discrete particle concepts through systematic integration methods. By treating objects as composed of infinitesimal mass elements and applying appropriate density functions, we can determine centers of mass for one-dimensional, two-dimensional, and three-dimensional objects of various geometries. The choice of coordinate system and integration strategy depends on object symmetry and geometry, with Cartesian coordinates suitable for rectangular shapes, polar/cylindrical coordinates optimal for circular geometries, and spherical coordinates most efficient for spherical objects. Both uniform and variable density distributions can be handled through proper integral setup, with symmetry principles often simplifying calculations. These techniques provide essential tools for analyzing real-world objects across engineering, physics, and technology applications, from structural design to vehicle stability to astronomical body analysis.
